Jinnō Shōtōki. p. 212. ==Events of the Eiman era== * 1165 (Eiman 1): The infant son of Emperor Nijō was named heir.Kitagawa, H. (1975). The Tale of the Heike, p.783. * 3 August 1165 (Eiman 1, 25th day of the 6th month): In the 7th year of Emperor Nijō's reign, the emperor abdicated; and the succession (senso) was received by a his son. Soon after, Emperor Rokujō accepted the monarch's role and duties and powers (sokui).Titsingh, p. 194; Brown, p. 329. This was confirmed in ceremonies.Varley, p. 44; a distinct act of senso is unrecognized prior to Emperor Tenji; and all sovereigns except Jitō, Yōzei, Go-Toba, and Fushimi have senso and sokui in the same year until the reign of Emperor Go-Murakami. Compare Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō), Ceremony of Accession (Sokui-no- Rei); retrieved 2012-2-23. * 4 September 1165 (Eiman 1, 27th day of the 7th month): Former-Emperor Nijō died at age 22.Brown, p. 328; Kitagawa, p.783; Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō), 二条天皇 (78); retrieved 2012-5-18. ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Eiman 1st 2nd Gregorian 1165 1166 Preceded by: Chōkan Era or nengō: Eiman Succeeded by: Nin'an Category:Japanese eras
